We feel fairly confident that word has spread that schools are closed for the next two weeks, March 16-27. Early this evening, we attempted to send a mass notification to families via email, text, and voice message; however, delivery results indicate that a much smaller percentage of families received our message than usual. We believe that mobile network outages played a part, but also, our current electronic notification system is used by multiple school divisions across the state and likely is backlogged by an unusually high volume of messaging, which led to sluggish delivery.

In case you missed it, you can access all of our COVID-19-related messaging on our website at www.k12albemarle.org/coronavirus.

Henley Student Art Exhibit at Center I

More than 60 projects by Henley Middle School Students are on display through October 31 at Center I, the school division’s most recent innovation hub. Cartoons, contour-line drawing, scientifically-inspired botanic illustrations, inky figural pictures, and modular geometric structures appear. Notecards, paper, upcycled surplus price tags, and wallpainters' dropcloth-paper are among the drawing and painting surfaces used.

The Henley student art exhibit is located on the first floor of Center 1, where its Main Street hallway intersects with a second-and-a-half streer corridor. The center is located on the second floor of Seminole Place, a multi-use repurposed light-industrial building at the intersection of Route 29 and Greenbrier Drive. Parking is available behind the building, off of Greenbrier Drive.

2019 VSBA High School Student Video Contest

The Virginia School Boards Association is asking Virginia high school students to express their thoughts and ideas around the theme “Virginia is For Learners” through our eighth annual student video contest. Students are invited to submit a 30 second video that conveys the contest theme. The top 3 videos, along with those identified by the judges as honorable mentions, will be posted on VSBA’s YouTube site, and winners will be honored at the VSBA Annual Convention in November.

For more information on how to submit video entries, please see the attached PDF. Information is also available on the VSBA website. PLEASE NOTE: Only ONE submission per school division will be accepted.

The submission deadline is October 4, 2019. **Each student participant listed must complete a Release Form**

If you have any questions, please contact Jessica Blythe, assistant director of membership services and communications at jessica@vsba.org or by calling 434-295-8722.

During the sales tax holiday, shoppers can buy qualifying school supplies ($20 or less per item) and clothing and footwear ($100 or less per item) without paying sales tax. Plus, items do not need to be purchased for school use or in connection with a school activity to be eligible for the exemption.

You can find school supply lists posted on the homepages of our elementary and middle schools. Please contact your child’s school if you have any questions about the requested supplies.

"History is the Present" discusses the educational experiences of African Americans in the County of Albemarle from emancipation to desegregation, as told by Lorenzo Dickerson, a graduate of Albemarle County Public Schools. It is a reminder that the impact of that story is present today through current personal experiences, inherited generational understandings, decision-making, and even in the names of school buildings. This presentation originally was delivered to the teachers of Western Albemarle High School as part of their professional development series and was seen by the Albemarle County Public School Board on October 18, 2018.

Subsequently, the Board directed Dr. Matthew Haas, the Superintendent of Schools, to review the policy for naming schools buildings and to make recommendations on whether the policy should be revised and how a new policy should be applied to existing buildings.

While the expected impact may have lessened, the potential for severe weather in Albemarle County still exists. The school division remains cautious and watchful, and we continue to monitor weather updates closely.

We have not yet made a decision about school operations on Friday. We will assess the situation on Thursday afternoon using the most up-to-date information. Our goal is to provide you with as much advanced notice as possible concerning any change to the school schedule.

A number of parents have asked on Facebook why we did not make the decision to close schools last evening rather than early this morning. We understand why this would have been a benefit to our families.

As of last evening, we did not have sufficient data about the conditions of the 7,000 miles of roads that are traveled by our buses every morning. Temperature forecasts last night for roads and bridges throughout the county this morning were not conclusive in determining the extent to which icing would occur.

Our most informed approach under such circumstances is to visually inspect the roads as close to our school start time as possible but in time to let parents know as early as possible if schools needed to be closed or openings delayed. We sent our road inspectors out at 2 a.m. Based upon when those inspections and our safety analysis was completed, we were able to make a decision by 5 a.m. It will continue to be our objective to make decisions about school openings and closings as early as allowed by the verifiable data.

A number of parents have asked on Facebook why we did not make the decision to close schools last evening rather than early this morning. We understand why this would have been a benefit to our families.

As of last evening, we did not have sufficient data about the conditions of the 7,000 miles of roads that are traveled by our buses every morning. Temperature forecasts last night for roads and bridges throughout the county this morning were not conclusive in determining the extent to which icing would occur.

Our most informed approach under such circumstances is to visually inspect the roads as close to our school start time as possible but in time to let parents know as early as possible if schools needed to be closed or openings delayed. We sent our road inspectors out at 2 a.m. Based upon when those inspections and our safety analysis was completed, we were able to make a decision by 5 a.m. It will continue to be our objective to make decisions about school openings and closings as early as allowed by the verifiable data.
